awd_titl_txt: Research Initiation Award - Cellulosic Ethanol Production from Major Feedstocks: Insights from Yeast Transcriptomics
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities-Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) Research Initiation Awards (RIAs) provide support to STEM junior faculty at HBCUs who are starting to build a research program, as well as for mid-career faculty who may have returned to the faculty ranks after holding an administrative post or who need to redirect and rebuild a research program. Faculty members may pursue research at their home institution, at an NSF-funded Center, at a research intensive institution or at a national laboratory. The RIA projects are expected to help further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, to improve research and teaching at his or her home institution, and to involve undergraduate students in research experiences. With support from the National Science Foundation, Alcorn State University (ASU) will conduct research aimed at understanding cellulosic ethanol production from major feedstocks. This research will be used to enhance teaching and learning at ASU and thus, the PI will gain hands-on training in yeast transcriptomics which the PI expects to utilize as a tool in optimizing production of other bioproducts. Alcorn State University, a land-grant minority institution, recently included a dedicated bioenergy program to diversify its agriculture curriculum and research portfolio. This research will complement these ongoing bioenergy initiatives at Alcorn State University.  Presently, Alcorn State does not have researchers engaged in "omics" research and this will ensure the expansion of Alcorn's research portfolio. The research and educational efforts will contribute to the University's goal to increase the number of minority students receiving BS degrees in STEM fields. This project will allow the PI to incorporate genomics research in his future projects and students to obtain hands-on research and training. The skills obtained from this research will not only help prepare students for careers in cellulosic ethanol and biofuel research but will be valuable for their graduate education and/or career. 

The goal of the proposed study is to characterize the transcriptome profile of S. cerevisiae and use it as a proxy to decode the impact of major feedstocks on overall ethanol production. Specifically, this project aims to conduct yeast transcriptomic profiling from cellulosic fermentation of four major feedstocks namely corn stover, switchgrass, Freedom Giant Miscanthus (FGM) and hybrid poplar. Results from this study will provide a blue-print of S. cerevisiae transcriptomic behavior during fermentation. This study has the potential to make significant contributions to understanding cellulosic ethanol production from the perspective of yeast genomics and provide baseline data for future development or engineering of industrial yeast strains for optimal ethanol production. The proposed RIA research will complement ongoing bioenergy initiatives at Alcorn State University. This project will be conducted in collaboration with Kansas State University.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of the project was to understand S. cerevisiae transcriptomics during fuel ethanol production from both, simultaneous saccharification and fermentation (SSF) and separate hydrolysis and fermentation (SHF) of four major feedstocks namely corn stover, switchgrass, Giant Miscanthus and hybrid poplar.The evaluation of the yeast transcriptomics was carried out in both simultaneous saccharification and fermentation (SSF) and separate hydrolysis and fermentation (SHF). The transcriptomic data has provided an insight into yeast genetics during fermentation. The up regulation and down regulation of genes and behavior during different conditions has helped us to infer the key roles of biosynthetic pathways that are influenced by fermentation type and feedstock. This information is very vital for synthetic biologist to develop unique strains for optimal ethanol production.  Apart from the transcriptomic information benefitting the scientists in bioenergy, the bioreactor systems purchased from the RIA project helped to train underrepresented students in bioprocessing and fermentation technology, where there is huge demand for well trained work force in bioenergy sector and beyond. The PI has integrated the laboratory set up to conduct experiments involving undergraduate students in his courses gain hand on experience of biofuel production. This funding helped the PI to train at least eight undergraduate students and three graduate students on various aspects of bioprocessing and bioenergy. Two of the undergraduate students went of purse doctoral degrees in STEM area. The funding has assisted in setting up of state-of-the-art bioprocessing facility at Alcorn State University to provide specialized training in fermentation and bioprocessing for minority and underrepresented students for year to come. This RIA study of the comparison of transcriptomics of an industrial S. cerevisiae (ATCC 24860) strain is novel as it will provide a blueprint of yeast transcriptional behavior during biofuel ethanol fermentation of corn stover, hybrid poplar, switchgrass and giant Miscanthus. Presently, only two commercial cellulosic plants are functional in the U.S. and most information about fermentation conditions and type of strain used for cellulosic ethanol fermentation remains proprietary. Accordingly, fermentation conditions that will be outlined in this study will follow those generally accepted by the research community and prescribed by the national laboratories. Since future cellulosic ethanol production will see the use of yeast (natural or engineered) with tolerance to multiple stresses, a natural strain (ATCC 24860) with high resistance to mixtures of inhibitors, very high tolerance to pH and ethanol is chosen for comparative transcriptomics.Transcriptomic data analysis for biochemical pathways that have been significantly influenced the ethanol production process has been studied. A clear picture has been emerged with respect to some of the central pathways such as glycolysis, oxidative phosphorylation, carbohydrate transportation. interestingly alcohol dehydrogenase, pyruvate decarboxylase genes and genes associated with glycolysis are significantly upregulated in separate hydrolysis and fermentation compared to simultaneous saccharification and fermentation. Switchgrass resulted in significantly upregulated glycolysis genes compared to miscanthus, and a similar trend has also noticed in poplar and corn stover. We are investigating the stress response genes in fermentation under different fermentation conditions. The findings from this research and the methods is likely to impact second generation biofuel industry. For example, the transcriptomic data of S. cerevisiae in different feedstocks from the study will serve as a starting point for understanding of yeast behavior in cellulosic fermentation medium. This will enable synthetic biologist to design strains that better suited for fermentation based on substrates. 



Last Modified: 10/29/2022
Modified by: Ananda Nanjundaswamy
